objectives.description: Identify the differences between federal and state taxes and understand how each affects your income.
Understand how progressive tax brackets work and why you don't pay the top rate on all your income.
Recognize payroll taxes (FICA) and understand their purpose in funding Social Security and Medicare.
Analyze how tax structures vary across states and how this impacts financial decisions.

terms.definition: A tax system where higher-income earners pay a higher percentage of their income in taxes.
terms.example: Federal income tax: 10% on first $11K, 12% on next $33K, 22% on amounts above that.

terms.definition: An income range that is subject to a specific tax rate in a progressive tax system.

layoutData.title: Taxes Pay for Public Services We All Use
paragraphs: When you pay taxes, you're contributing to a wide range of programs and infrastructure that benefit society:
bulletPoints: Education: Public schools, colleges, student aid programs
Public Safety: Police, fire departments, emergency services

leftPanel.title: The Common Misconception
paragraphs: Many people think: "If I'm in the 22% bracket, I pay 22% on ALL my income."
This is wrong! You only pay each rate on income within that specific bracket.

leftPanel.title: What FICA Funds
paragraphs: Social Security (6.2%): Retirement benefits, disability income, survivor benefits for families.
Medicare (1.45%): Healthcare coverage for those 65+ and certain disabled individuals.
Your employer matches your contribution, meaning 15.3% total goes to these programs for every dollar you earn.

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Tax Knowledge = Better Financial Decisions
paragraphs: Understanding how taxes work helps you in multiple areas of life:
bulletPoints: Job Offers: Compare after-tax income, not just salary numbers
Budgeting: Know your actual take-home pay before committing to expenses
Location: Consider total tax burden when choosing where to live
Retirement: Pre-tax contributions (401k) reduce your taxable income now
Side Income: Self-employment means paying both halves of FICA (15.3%)
Investments: Different investment income has different tax treatment

takeaways.title: Progressive System
takeaways.description: Federal tax rates increase with income, but only income in each bracket is taxed at that rate
